input: [STYLE]
output: Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them, If any man of you bring an offering unto the LORD, ye shall bring your offering of the cattle, even of the herd, and of the flock.

input: [STYLE]
output: If his offering be a burnt sacrifice of the herd, let him offer a male without blemish: he shall offer it of his own voluntary will at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD.

input: [STYLE]
output: And he shall put his hand upon the head of the burnt offering; and it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him.

input: [STYLE]
output: And he shall kill the bullock before the LORD: and the priests, Aaron's sons, shall bring the blood, and sprinkle the blood round about upon the altar that is by the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.

input: [STYLE]
output: And he shall flay the burnt offering, and cut it into his pieces.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the sons of Aaron the priest shall put fire upon the altar, and lay the wood in order upon the fire:

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thou bring an oblation of a meat offering baken in the oven, it shall be unleavened cakes of fine flour mingled with oil, or unleavened wafers anointed with oil.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thy oblation be a meat offering baken in a pan, it shall be of fine flour unleavened, mingled with oil.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thou shalt part it in pieces, and pour oil thereon: it is a meat offering.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thy oblation be a meat offering baken in the fryingpan, it shall be made of fine flour with oil.

input: [STYLE]
output: And thou shalt bring the meat offering that is made of these things unto the LORD: and when it is presented unto the priest, he shall bring it unto the altar.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the LORD said unto Moses, Speak unto the priests the sons of Aaron, and say unto them, There shall none be defiled for the dead among his people:

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thou offer a meat offering of thy firstfruits unto the LORD, thou shalt offer for the meat offering of thy firstfruits green ears of corn dried by the fire, even corn beaten out of full ears.

input: [STYLE]
output: And he shall lay his hand upon the head of his offering, and kill it at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation: and Aaron's sons the priests shall sprinkle the blood upon the altar round about.

input: [STYLE]
output: Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, If a soul shall sin through ignorance against any of the commandments of the LORD concerning things which ought not to be done, and shall do against any of them:

input: [STYLE]
output: If the priest that is anointed do sin according to the sin of the people; then let him bring for his sin, which he hath sinned, a young bullock without blemish unto the LORD for a sin offering.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if he be not able to bring a lamb, then he shall bring for his trespass, which he hath committed, two turtledoves, or two young pigeons, unto the LORD; one for a sin offering, and the other for a burnt offering.

output: And he shall offer the second for a burnt offering, according to the manner: and the priest shall make an atonement for him for his sin which he hath sinned, and it shall be forgiven him.

output: Of their flesh shall ye not eat, and their carcase shall ye not touch; they are unclean to you.

output: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour draws on apace; four happy days bring in another moon.

output: Like to a step-dame or a dowager long withering out a young man revenue.

output: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for they shall be filled.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.

input: [STYLE]
output: Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost his savour, wherewith shall it be salted? it is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye are the light of the world. A city that is set on an hill cannot be hid.

input: [STYLE]
output: Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel, but on a candlestick; and it giveth light unto all that are in the house.

input: [STYLE]
output: Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.

input: [STYLE]
output: For verily I say unto you, Till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled.

input: [STYLE]
output: Whosoever therefore shall break one of these least commandments, and shall teach men so, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven: but whosoever shall do and teach them, the same shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: For I say unto you, That except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not kill; and whosoever shall kill shall be in danger of the judgment:

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, That whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment: and whosoever shall say to his brother, Raca, shall be in danger of the council: but whosoever shall say, Thou fool, shall be in danger of hell fire.

input: [STYLE]
output: Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thee;

input: [STYLE]
output: Leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.

input: [STYLE]
output: Agree with thine adversary quickly, whiles thou art in the way with him; lest at any time the adversary deliver thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officer, and thou be cast into prison.

input: [STYLE]
output: Verily I say unto thee, Thou shalt by no means come out thence, till thou hast paid the uttermost farthing.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not commit adultery:

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, That whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if thy right hand offend thee, cut it off, and cast it from thee: for it is profitable for thee that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into hell.

input: [STYLE]
output: It hath been said, Whosoever shall put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement:

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, That whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery: and whosoever shall marry her that is divorced committeth adultery.

input: [STYLE]
output: Again, ye have heard that it hath been said by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths:

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, Swear not at all; neither by heaven; for it is God's throne:

input: [STYLE]
output: Nor by the earth; for it is his footstool: neither by Jerusalem; for it is the city of the great King.

input: [STYLE]
output: Neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because thou canst not make one hair white or black.

input: [STYLE]
output: But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye have heard that it hath been said, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth:

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also.

input: [STYLE]
output: And if any man will sue thee at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloke also.

input: [STYLE]
output: And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him twain.

input: [STYLE]
output: Give to him that asketh thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ye have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy.

input: [STYLE]
output: But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;

input: [STYLE]
output: That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.

input: [STYLE]
output: For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? do not even the publicans the same?

input: [STYLE]
output: And if ye salute your brethren only, what do ye more than others? do not even the publicans so?

input: [STYLE]
output: Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect.

input: [STYLE]
output: Take heed that ye do not your alms before men, to be seen of them: otherwise ye have no reward of your Father which is in heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Therefore when thou doest thine alms, do not sound a trumpet before thee, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may have glory of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

input: [STYLE]
output: But when thou doest alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth:

input: [STYLE]
output: That thine alms may be in secret: and thy Father which seeth in secret himself shall reward thee openly.

input: [STYLE]
output: And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are: for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

input: [STYLE]
output: But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee openly.

input: [STYLE]
output: But when ye pray, use not vain repetitions, as the heathen do: for they think that they shall be heard for their much speaking.

input: [STYLE]
output: Be not ye therefore like unto them: for your Father knoweth what things ye have need of, before ye ask him.

input: [STYLE]
output: After this manner therefore pray ye: Our Father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heaven.

input: [STYLE]
output: Give us this day our daily bread.

input: [STYLE]
output: And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.

input: [STYLE]
output: And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil: For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever. Amen.

input: [STYLE]
output: For if ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you:

input: [STYLE]
output: But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses.

input: [STYLE]
output: Moreover when ye fast, be not, as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance: for they disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.

input: [STYLE]
output: But thou, when thou fastest, anoint thine head, and wash thy face;

input: [STYLE]
output: That thou appear not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father which is in secret: and thy Father, which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly.

input: [STYLE]
output: Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal:

input: [STYLE]
output: But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal:

input: [STYLE]
output: For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.

input: [STYLE]
output: The light of the body is the eye: if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light.

input: [STYLE]
output: But if thine eye be evil, thy whole body shall be full of darkness. If therefore the light that is in thee be darkness, how great is that darkness!

input: [STYLE]
output: No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.

input: [STYLE]
output: Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?

input: [STYLE]
output: Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father feedeth them. Are ye not much better than they?

input: [STYLE]
output: Which of you by taking thought can add one cubit unto his stature?

input: [STYLE]
output: And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin:

input: [STYLE]
output: And yet I say unto you, That even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.

input: [STYLE]
output: Wherefore, if God so clothe the grass of the field, which to day is, and to morrow is cast into the oven, shall he not much more clothe you, O ye of little faith?

input: [STYLE]
output: Therefore take no thought, saying, What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? or, Wherewithal shall we be clothed?

input: [STYLE]
output: (For after all these things do the Gentiles seek:) for your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things.

input: [STYLE]
output: But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you.

input: [STYLE]
output: Take therefore no thought for the morrow: for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself. Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.

input: [STYLE]
output: From the Apocrypha: Bel and the Dragon.

input: [STYLE]
output: And king Astyages was gathered to his fathers, and Cyrus of Persia received his kingdom.

input: [STYLE]
output: And Daniel conversed with the king, and was honoured above all his friends.

input: [STYLE]
output: Now the Babylonians had an idol called Bel: and there were spent upon him every day twelve great measures of fine flour, and forty sheep, and six vessels of wine.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the king worshipped it and went daily to adore it: but Daniel worshipped his own God. And the king said unto him, Why dost not thou worship Bel?

input: [STYLE]
output: Who answered and said, Because I may not worship idols made with hands, but the living God, who hath created the heaven and the earth, and hath sovereignty over all flesh.

input: [STYLE]
output: Then said the king unto him, Thinkest thou not that Bel is a living god? seest thou not how much he eateth and drinketh every day?

input: [STYLE]
output: Then Daniel smiled, and said, O king, be not deceived: for this is but clay within, and brass without, and did never eat or drink anything.

input: [STYLE]
output: So the king was wroth, and called for his priests, and said unto them, If ye tell me not who this is that devoureth these expenses, ye shall die.

input: [STYLE]
output: But if ye can certify me that Bel devoureth them, then Daniel shall die: for he hath spoken blasphemy against Bel. And Daniel said unto the king, Let it be according to thy word.

input: [STYLE]
output: Now the priests of Bel were threescore and ten, beside their wives and children. And the king went with Daniel into the temple of Bel.

input: [STYLE]
output: So Bel’s priests said, Lo, we go out: but thou, O king, set on the meat, and make ready the wine, and shut the door fast, and seal it with thine own signet:

input: [STYLE]
output: And tomorrow when thou comest in, if thou findest not that Bel hath eaten up all, we will suffer death: or else Daniel, that speaketh falsely against us.

input: [STYLE]
output: And they little regarded it: for under the table they had made a privy entrance, whereby they entered in continually, and consumed those things.

input: [STYLE]
output: So when they were gone forth, the king set meats before Bel. Now Daniel had commanded his servants to bring ashes, and those they strewed throughout all the temple in the presence of the king alone: then went they out, and shut the door, and sealed it with the king’s signet, and so departed.

input: [STYLE]
output: Now in the night came the priests with their wives and children, as they were wont, and did eat and drink up all.

input: [STYLE]
output: In the morning betimes the king arose, and Daniel with him.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the king said, Daniel, hath Bel eaten up the meat? And Daniel said, O king, live for ever.

input: [STYLE]
output: But look upon the pavement, and mark well whose footsteps are these.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the king said, I see the footsteps of men, women, and children. And then the king was angry,

input: [STYLE]
output: And took the priests with their wives and children, who shewed him the privy doors, where they came in and consumed such things as were upon the table.

input: [STYLE]
output: Therefore the king slew them, and delivered Bel into Daniel’s power, who destroyed him and his temple.

input: [STYLE]
output: And in that same place there was a great dragon, which they of Babylon worshipped.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the king said unto Daniel, Wilt thou also say that this is of brass? lo, he liveth, he eateth and drinketh; thou canst not say that he is no living god: therefore worship him.

input: [STYLE]
output: Then said Daniel unto the king, I will worship the Lord my God: for he is the living God.

input: [STYLE]
output: But give me leave, O king, and I shall slay this dragon without sword or staff. And the king said, I give thee leave.

input: [STYLE]
output: Then Daniel took pitch, and fat, and hair, and did seethe them together, and made lumps thereof: this he put in the dragon’s mouth, and so the dragon burst in sunder: and Daniel said, Lo, these are the gods ye worship.

input: [STYLE]
output: When they of Babylon heard that, they took great indignation, and conspired against the king.

input: [STYLE]
output: So the king saw that they pressed him sore, being constrained, he delivered Daniel unto them:

input: [STYLE]
output: Who cast him into the lions’ den: where he was six days.

input: [STYLE]
output: And in the den there were seven lions, and they had given them every day two carcasses and two sheep: which then were not given to them, to the intent they might devour Daniel.

input: [STYLE]
output: Now there was in Jewry a prophet, called Habakkuk, who had made pottage, and had broken bread in a bowl, and was going into the field, for to carry it to the reapers.

input: [STYLE]
output: But the angel of the Lord said unto Habakkuk, Go, carry the dinner that thou hast into Babylon unto Daniel, who is in the lions’ den.

input: [STYLE]
output: And Habakkuk said, Lord, I never saw Babylon; neither do I know where the den is.

input: [STYLE]
output: Then the angel of the Lord took him by the hair of the head, and carried him by the hair of his head, and through the vehemency of his spirit set him in Babylon over the den.

input: [STYLE]
output: And Habakkuk cried, saying, O Daniel, Daniel, take the dinner which God hath sent thee.

input: [STYLE]
output: And Daniel said, Thou hast remembered me, O God: neither hast thou forsaken them that seek thee and love thee.

input: [STYLE]
output: So Daniel arose, and did eat: and the angel of the Lord set Habakkuk in his own place again immediately.

input: [STYLE]
output: Upon the seventh day the king went to bewail Daniel: and when he came to the den, he looked in, and behold, Daniel was sitting.

input: [STYLE]
output: Then cried the king with a loud voice, saying, Great art thou, O Lord God of Daniel, and there is none other beside thee.

input: [STYLE]
output: And he drew him out, and cast those that were the cause of his destruction into the den: and they were devoured in a moment before his face.

input: [STYLE]
output: And God said, Let there be light: and there was light.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the LORD God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.

input: [STYLE]
output: And the LORD said unto Noah, Come thou and all thy house into the ark; for thee have I seen righteous before me in this generation.

input: [STYLE]
output: A gentle knight rode forth upon the plain, bearing a red cross upon his shield.

input: [STYLE]
output: Beside him went fair Una, a lady pure and true, guiding his quest with heavenly grace.

input: [STYLE]
output: They entered a dark wood, where shadows thickened and the path grew perilous.

input: [STYLE]
output: Long they wandered, till they came upon a den where dwelt a monstrous creature called Error.

input: [STYLE]
output: The beast was half serpent and half woman, with a brood of young that clung about her.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight drew his sword and struck boldly, but Error coiled round him with her tail.

input: [STYLE]
output: She spewed forth foul vomit of books and papers, choking the air with lies and poison.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight faltered, but Una cried to him to trust in God and strike again.

input: [STYLE]
output: With renewed strength he smote the monster’s head, cleaving it in twain.

input: [STYLE]
output: Her brood, seeing their mother slain, fled shrieking into the wilderness.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thus was Error destroyed, and the knight emerged victorious, guided still by Una’s truth.

input: [STYLE]
output: They pressed onward through the forest, though the path was tangled and uncertain.

input: [STYLE]
output: Soon they encountered a hermit, who seemed holy and wise, offering them shelter.

input: [STYLE]
output: But this was Archimago, a false enchanter, who plotted deceit against the knight.

input: [STYLE]
output: He conjured spirits to weave illusions, crafting false dreams to ensnare the knight’s mind.

input: [STYLE]
output: In visions the knight beheld Una unfaithful, and his heart was troubled.

input: [STYLE]
output: Archimago rejoiced in his craft, for he had sown discord between truth and holiness.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight, deceived, turned away from Una, though she remained pure and steadfast.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una wept, yet trusted still in God, and continued her path alone.

input: [STYLE]
output: Night fell, and the enchanter prepared his mischief, bidding wicked sprites to his service.

input: [STYLE]
output: He sent one spirit down to the dusky halls of sleep, where Morpheus keeps his drowsy court.

input: [STYLE]
output: There the sprite gathered a dream, heavy with false delight and treacherous show.

input: [STYLE]
output: Returning swift, it laid the dream upon the knight, whispering soft delusion in his ear.

input: [STYLE]
output: Archimago then shaped a false semblance of Una, fair in face but foul in will.

input: [STYLE]
output: Beside her he set another sprite, feigning as a lewd squire, to play the paramour.

input: [STYLE]
output: They acted a wanton scene, with stolen kisses and unchaste embrace.

input: [STYLE]
output: Awaking, the knight beheld the counterfeit, and his heart was pierced with grief and wrath.

input: [STYLE]
output: He turned his eyes from truth, not knowing he gazed upon a mask of lies.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una slept in innocence, unknowing of the treachery that worked beside her.

input: [STYLE]
output: The false pair withdrew as dawn drew nigh, leaving the knight in a storm of doubt.

input: [STYLE]
output: Ere sunrise, he rose in haste, and with a heavy spirit took up his arms.

input: [STYLE]
output: He looked upon Una, yet suspicion veiled his sight, and he would not trust.

input: [STYLE]
output: Without farewell, he left the place, riding through the misted wood alone.

input: [STYLE]
output: Archimago, spying his departure, smiled darkly, for his net had snared the prey.

input: [STYLE]
output: The enchanter then pursued at distance, weaving further wiles to deepen the divide.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una awoke and found the knight departed, and sorrow weighed her gentle breast.

input: [STYLE]
output: She called his name among the trees, but only echoes answered in the leaves.

input: [STYLE]
output: Her tears fell like dew upon the grass, yet steadfastly she prayed for his return.

input: [STYLE]
output: The wood grew wild with briar and thorn, as if the very path conspired against her.

input: [STYLE]
output: Still she held to truth, the only light in that dark maze of ill intent.

input: [STYLE]
output: Meanwhile the knight rode swift, seeking to escape the thought that wounded him.

input: [STYLE]
output: His shield, though bright, seemed heavy; his helm, though strong, pressed hard upon his brow.

input: [STYLE]
output: He remembered his victory over Error, yet doubt gnawed like a hidden worm.

input: [STYLE]
output: From shadowed thickets, Archimago loosed new phantoms to dog the knight’s steps.

input: [STYLE]
output: They whispered flatteries and fears, now praising his zeal, now pricking his pride.

input: [STYLE]
output: The enchanter posed as a holy guide, offering counsel that crooked truth to his design.

input: [STYLE]
output: He told of dangers that Una would bring, and of safer paths that led elsewhere.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thus with honeyed speech he fed the knight’s suspicion, as bees are lured to poison-sweet.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight, unpractised in the arts of guile, mistook the serpent’s hiss for wisdom’s voice.

input: [STYLE]
output: He vowed to prove his holiness alone, as if truth were a burden he must lay aside.

input: [STYLE]
output: So virtue walked unyoked from truth, and stumbled where it should have stood upright.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una, patient in her grief, kept faithful course, though the forest mocked her with winding ways.

input: [STYLE]
output: She prayed that light might pierce her path, and that the knight be guarded from ill.

input: [STYLE]
output: Birds ceased their morning song as clouds drew low, foretelling trials yet to come.

input: [STYLE]
output: Archimago, tireless in malice, prepared new masks to lead the knight astray.

input: [STYLE]
output: He dressed lies in robes of truth, and set falsehood upon a borrowed throne.

input: [STYLE]
output: He taught the knight to doubt his guide, and to lean upon his own uncertain will.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thus was the seed of ruin sown, watered by pride, and warmed by jealousy’s sun.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight pressed onward, hearing only the echo of his wounded thought.

input: [STYLE]
output: His courage, though great, lacked the counsel that makes valour wise.

input: [STYLE]
output: So ends the first trial with Error slain, yet begins the subtler war with seeming good.

input: [STYLE]
output: For monsters of the den are easily known, but those that wear fair faces are harder to discern.

input: [STYLE]
output: And in that dark wood, truth and holiness parted ways, not by fate, but by deceit.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight approached the dragon’s lair, his heart steadfast though the ground trembled beneath him.

input: [STYLE]
output: The beast lay stretched in dreadful length, scales glistening like iron and wings vast as clouds.

input: [STYLE]
output: Its eyes burned like twin furnaces, casting sparks upon the air with every glance.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon rose, shaking the earth, and roared so loud that the heavens quaked.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight lifted his shield, bearing the red cross, and advanced with sword in hand.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon rushed forward, full of fire and greedy hardiment, bent on devouring him.

input: [STYLE]
output: Its fiery head struck with force, the noise resounding like thunder across the firmament.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight smote upon the monster’s scaly hide, sparks flying from the blow.

input: [STYLE]
output: The beast recoiled with a dreadful cry, yet from its mouth issued flames of fire.

input: [STYLE]
output: The flames scorched the ground, burning grass and stone, and singed the knight’s armour.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight pressed on, though wounded sore, trusting in God for strength.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon struck with its tail, sweeping the knight aside and casting him down.

input: [STYLE]
output: He lay bruised upon the earth, yet rose again, his spirit unbroken.

input: [STYLE]
output: The beast spread its wings, darkening the sky, and descended with crushing might.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight raised his shield, and the dragon’s claws scraped upon the iron cross.

input: [STYLE]
output: The battle raged from dawn till dusk, neither yielding, both fierce in strength.

input: [STYLE]
output: At last the knight stumbled near a well of living water, clear and pure.

input: [STYLE]
output: He drank and was refreshed, his wounds healed by the holy spring.

input: [STYLE]
output: Renewed, he rose with vigour, and struck the dragon with mighty force.

input: [STYLE]
output: The beast roared, shaking mountains, yet the knight stood firm.

input: [STYLE]
output: On the second day the dragon renewed its fury, striking with tail and claw.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight was cast down again, his armour rent and body sorely bruised.

input: [STYLE]
output: Yet near him grew a sacred tree, whose balm healed his wounds.

input: [STYLE]
output: He rested beneath its shade, and strength returned to his weary limbs.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon circled above, breathing fire, but the knight rose undaunted.

input: [STYLE]
output: He struck the beast’s wing, cleaving through the sinews, and it fell to earth.

input: [STYLE]
output: The ground shook with its fall, dust rising like smoke from the plain.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight pressed his advantage, driving his blade into the dragon’s side.

input: [STYLE]
output: The monster writhed in agony, its roar echoing across the land.

input: [STYLE]
output: On the third day the dragon gathered its strength for a final assault.

input: [STYLE]
output: It opened its jaws wide, flames pouring forth like rivers of fire.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight lifted his shield, the cross shining bright against the blaze.

input: [STYLE]
output: He prayed for divine aid, and courage filled his heart anew.

input: [STYLE]
output: With a swift stroke he pierced the dragon’s throat, driving deep into its flesh.

input: [STYLE]
output: Blood poured forth, and the beast staggered, its strength failing.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon fell lifeless to the earth, its body stretched across the plain.

input: [STYLE]
output: The land was delivered, freed from terror and fire.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una rejoiced, her prayers answered, and truth restored to its place.

input: [STYLE]
output: The people came forth, praising the knight for his victory.

input: [STYLE]
output: Songs were sung of the dragon slain, and of holiness triumphant.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight gave thanks to God, knowing his strength was not his own.

input: [STYLE]
output: He stood beside Una, their bond renewed by trial and triumph.

input: [STYLE]
output: The land flourished once more, fields green and rivers clear.

input: [STYLE]
output: The terror of the dragon was remembered only in tale and song.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight’s armour bore scars of battle, yet his spirit shone brighter.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una’s faith had guided him, and together they stood as symbols of truth and holiness.

input: [STYLE]
output: The people crowned him their champion, defender of the land and slayer of the beast.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon’s carcass lay as proof of victory, its scales dull and lifeless.

input: [STYLE]
output: Children played in safety, no longer fearing fire or claw.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight rested, his quest fulfilled, though greater duties yet awaited him.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una smiled, her sorrow turned to joy, for truth had prevailed.

input: [STYLE]
output: The heavens seemed brighter, as if creation itself rejoiced in the triumph.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight’s name was honoured, his deeds proclaimed in every hall.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thus ended the battle with the dragon, a tale of courage and divine aid.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight prepared to continue his service to the Faerie Queene.

input: [STYLE]
output: Una remained by his side, steadfast companion and guide.

input: [STYLE]
output: Together they looked to the future, where new trials would surely rise.

input: [STYLE]
output: But for that moment, peace reigned, and the land was free.

input: [STYLE]
output: The dragon’s fall marked the triumph of holiness over evil.

input: [STYLE]
output: The knight’s wounds bore witness to the cost of victory.

input: [STYLE]
output: Yet his spirit was unbroken, his faith unshaken, his courage proven.

input: [STYLE]
output: So the tale of the dragon fight was told, and the knight’s glory endured.

input: [STYLE]
output: Thus Canto XI closed, with triumph, thanksgiving, and the promise of greater quests to come.

input: [STYLE]

input: [STYLE]

input: [STYLE]

input: [STYLE]
output: The merciless Macdonwald— Worthy to be a rebel, for to that The multiplying villanies of nature Do swarm upon him—from the western isles Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied; And fortune, on his damned quarrel smiling, Show'd like a rebel's whore: but all's too weak; For brave Macbeth—well he deserves that name— Disdaining fortune, with his brandish'd steel, Which smoked with bloody execution, Like valour's minion carved out his passage Till he faced the slave; Which ne'er shook hands, nor bade farewell to him, Till he unseam'd him from the nave to the chaps, And fix'd his head upon our battlements.

input: [STYLE]
output: O valiant cousin! worthy gentleman!

input: [STYLE]
output: Dismay'd not this Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?

input: [STYLE]
output: Yes; As sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.

input: [STYLE]
output: If I say sooth, I must report they were As cannons overcharged with double cracks; So they Doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe: Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds, Or memorise another Golgotha, I cannot tell.

input: [STYLE]

input: [STYLE]
output: Till that Bellona's bridegroom, lapp'd in proof, Confronted him with self-comparisons, Point against point rebellious, arm 'gainst arm, Curbing his lavish spirit.

input: [STYLE]
output: And, to conclude, The victory fell on us.

input: [STYLE]
output: Great happiness.

input: [STYLE]

input: [STYLE]

output: Your children shall be kings.

input: [STYLE]
output: But 'tis strange.

output: Cousins, a word, I pray you.

output: Two truths are told, As happy prologues to the swelling act Of the imperial theme.

input: [STYLE]
output: SCENE IV. Forres. The palace.

output: O worthiest cousin.

output: Your highness' part Is to receive our duties.

input: [STYLE]
output: There if I grow, The harvest is your own.

input: [STYLE]
output: My plenteous joys, Wanton in fulness, seek to hide themselves In drops of sorrow.

output: Sons, kinsmen, thanes, And you whose places are the nearest, know We will establish our estate upon Our eldest, Malcolm, whom we name hereafter The Prince of Cumberland.

input: [STYLE]
output: Which honour must Not unaccompanied invest him only, But signs of nobleness, like stars, shall shine On all deservers.

input: [STYLE]
output: From hence to Inverness, And bind us further to you.

input: [STYLE]
